clusters.title: Police recover swallowed Fabergé pendant after 6-day wait for it to reappear
clusters.neutral_headline: Police Recover Swallowed Fabergé Pendant

items.title: Police recover swallowed Fabergé pendant after 6-day wait for it to reappear
items.standfirst: New Zealand police say they have recovered a James Bond-inspired Fabergé pendant after six days of closely watching the man accused of swallowing the jewellery.
items.content: New Zealand police say they have recovered a James Bond-inspired Fabergé pendant after six days of closely watching the man accused of swallowing the jewellery in an Auckland store.They said the pendant was recovered on Thursday night after it exited the suspect's gastrointestinal tract naturally without medical intervention.The limited-edition Fabergé egg pendant was inspired by the 1983 James Bond film Octopussy, in which a jewel-smuggling operation involves a fake Fabergé egg.READ MORE: Son of high-profile man found guilty of raping woman inside homeA less glamorous photo supplied by New Zealand's police today showed a gloved hand holding the recovered pendant and its long, gold chain with an intact price tag showing the jewellery's $NZ33,000 ($28,700) value.The man was arrested inside Partridge Jewellers in Auckland on November 28 shortly after the alleged theft.He made a court appearance November 29, when he didn't enter a plea to a charge of theft. Since then, he's been in police custody and officers had been stationed around the clock with the man to wait for the evidence to reemerge.The 32-year-old man has not been publicly named. He is due to appear in Auckland District Court on Monday and will remain in police custody until then."Given this man is in police custody, we have a duty of care to continue monitoring him given the circumstances of what has occurred," Inspector Grae Anderson said in a statement on Wednesday.The store's website says the egg, one of only 50 made, was crafted from gold, painted with green enamel and encrusted with 183 diamonds and two sapphires. The pendant is 8.4 centimetres tall and is mounted on a stand."The egg opens to reveal an 18ct yellow gold octopus nestled inside, adorned with white diamond suckers and black diamond eyes," an item description said. "The octopus surprise pays homage to the eponymous antagonist at the center of the Octopussy film."

items.title: NZ police recover Fabergé egg six days after suspect allegedly swallowed it
items.standfirst: Police officers were with the suspect around the clock until the stolen pendant was recovered.
items.content: Police officers were with the suspect around the clock until the stolen pendant was recovered.

ai_summary: Police recovered a Fabergé pendant.
The pendant was swallowed by a suspect.
Police watched the suspect for six days.
The pendant is James Bond-inspired.
The incident occurred in New Zealand.

clusters.title: Families of constables murdered in Wieambilla take legal action
clusters.neutral_headline: Families File Legal Action in Wieambilla Case

items.title: Families of constables murdered in Wieambilla take legal action
items.standfirst: The families of slain police officers Rachel McCrow and Matthew Arnold are launching legal action against NSW and Queensland police, arguing that negligence led to their deaths.
items.content: The families of slain police officers Rachel McCrow and Matthew Arnold are launching legal action against NSW and Queensland police, arguing that negligence led to their deaths.Constables McCrow, 29 and Arnold, 26, were ambushed and murdered by a trio of deluded conspiracy theorists in Wieambilla in 2022.An inquest last month found Gareth, Nathaniel and Stacey Train were "psychotically unwell" with a "shared delusional disorder", but not terrorists.READ MORE: Grief-stricken families disappointed by Wieambilla coronial findingsThe inquest also handed down 10 recommendations, including a review of the State Intelligence Group, QPS drone capabilities in remote locations, and issues of information sharing between law enforcement agencies.The families claim negligence by the NSW Police Force and Queensland Police Service ultimately led to the constables being dropped into a firefight they had no chance of surviving."They believe that pertinent evidence was overlooked and not fully considered," a statement from the families' lawyer reads."Our clients are confident that, but for the alleged negligence of the NSW Police Force and the Queensland Police Service, Constable Rachel McCrow and Constable Matthew Arnold would still be alive."They also want to ensure that the families of other police officers "never have to suffer the kind of pain and loss that they now endure".Both families have lodged separate claims in the Supreme Court in Brisbane.

items.title: Families of officers killed in Wieambilla attack launch action against police
items.standfirst: The families of the two officers murdered at Wieambilla in 2022 have made personal injury claims against Queensland and New South Wales police.
items.content: The families of the two officers murdered at Wieambilla in 2022 have made personal injury claims against Queensland and New South Wales police.

ai_summary: Families of slain constables are taking legal action.
The legal action is against NSW and Queensland police.
The families allege negligence led to deaths.
The officers were murdered in Wieambilla.
The officers were Rachel McCrow and Matthew Arnold.

clusters.title: Suspected human remains found after search for missing swimmer
clusters.neutral_headline: Suspected Human Remains Found on NSW Beach
bullet_summary: Suspected human remains have been found at a South West Rocks beach in northern NSW where an 18-year-old was swept out to sea five days ago
Suspected human remains have been found after the search for a missing swimmer near Coffs Harbour was suspended

items.title: Suspected human remains found after search for missing swimmer
items.standfirst: Suspected human remains have been found at a South West Rocks beach in northern NSW where an 18-year-old was swept out to sea five days ago.
items.content: Suspected human remains have been found at a South West Rocks beach in northern NSW where an 18-year-old was swept out to sea five days ago.

items.title: Suspected human remains found on NSW beach after swimmer's disappearance
items.standfirst: Suspected human remains have been found after the search for a missing swimmer near Coffs Harbour was suspended.
items.content: Suspected human remains have been found after the search for a missing swimmer on the NSW Mid North Coast was suspended.Astin Gerstl, a school leaver from The King's School in Sydney, got into trouble in the water at Little Bay Beach at South West Rocks, on the coast near Kempsey, about 4.20pm on Sunday.A search involving police and Surf Life Saving NSW over several days failed to locate the 18-year-old.This morning, police were called to the beach after a member of the public found what is believed to be human remains.The remains have been taken for forensic examination and a report will be prepared for the coroner. The King's School has offered support for Gerstl's graduating class and the wider community.

ai_summary: Suspected human remains were found on a beach.
The search for a missing swimmer was suspended.
The swimmer disappeared five days prior.
The location is South West Rocks, NSW.
The swimmer was eighteen years old.

clusters.title: Ayers Rock Resort operation being sold to US company
clusters.neutral_headline: Ayers Rock Resort Operations Sold to US Company

items.title: Ayers Rock Resort operation being sold to US company
items.standfirst: A deal for the sale of operations at Ayers Rock Resort, near Uluru, and the Mossman Gorge Cultural Centre, in Far North Queensland, is one step closer after the Indigenous Land and Sea Corporation reached an agreement with Journey Beyond, an Australian-based "experiential tourism" company owned by an American private equity firm.
